newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan's Nippon Credit to cut jobs, branches.
newsitem.headline: Japan's Nippon Credit to cut jobs, branches.

text.p: Japan's Nippon Credit Bank Ltd announced a major restructuring on Tuesday that will mean the loss of 600 jobs, the sale of prime real estate and a withdrawal from major overseas markets.

The troubled bank, one of Japan's long-term credit banks, also said that it would write off 460 billion yen ($3.70 billion) in bad loans for the 1996/97 financial year that ended on Monday and post a parent current loss of 350 billion yen ($2.82 billion) for the period.
Nippon Credit said last week it was working on a restructuring programme designed to strengthen its capital base. The bank is considered one of the weakest in the shaky Japanese banking sector.

It noted that the loss will be its second in the past two years. It said it is cutting executives' salaries by 50 percent. It said the sale of real estate would include its Tokyo headquarters and a branch office in Osaka, western Japan, from which it said it hopes to post a gain of 67 billion yen ($540 million).

Earlier on Tuesday, NCB put three of its non-bank financial subsidiaries into bankruptcy protection and the government announced that it would use money from a fund set up to help failed "jusen" mortgage firms to help bail out NCB.

NCB said it hoped the moves would boost its capital by 300 billion yen ($2.41 billion) and predicted that the restructuring would raise profitability by 50 billion yen ($403 million) over the next five years.
